msgSnippet: ... If your EJB has no publicly-available interface, then how can you write a client for it? Assuming your EJB has a local interface, then yes, I imagine a
messageBody:
karthik_guru2000 wrote:

> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
> wrote:
> > If you have a Local interface, yes. If there is no remote interface
> at
> > all, then I don't know how you would code /any/ client for that
> EJB, and
> > a Unit Test is just another client.
>
> But tell me something, does'nt Cactus solve this problem by executing
> the test methods in the same VM as the local EJBs?

If your EJB has no publicly-available interface, then how can you write
a client for it?

Assuming your EJB has a local interface, then yes, I imagine a Cactus
test would work wonderfully. Try it.
